column1: Solna Municipality (Swedish: Solna kommun or Solna stad
column2: IPA: [ˈsôːlna]) is a municipality in Stockholm County in Sweden
column3: located just north of the Stockholm City Centre. Its seat is located in the town of Solna
column4: which is a part of the Stockholm urban area.

column1: The municipality is a part of Metropolitan Stockholm. None of the area is considered rural
column2: which is unusual for Swedish municipalities
column3: which normally are of mixed rural/urban character. Solna is the third smallest municipality in Sweden in terms of area.

column1: Solna borders Stockholm Municipality to the south
column2: southeast and northwest; to Sundbyberg Municipality to the west; to Sollentuna Municipality to the north; and to Danderyd Municipality to the northeast. The boundary with Danderyd Municipality is delineated by the Stocksundet strait.

column1: There are two parishes in Solna Municipality: Råsunda (population 29
column2: 677) and Solna (population 28
column3: 317). Solna Parish once included parts of present-day City of Stockholm.Solna is divided into eight traditional parts with no administrative functions: Bergshamra
column9: Skytteholm and Ulriksdal. The largest districts are Råsunda
column11: with the Solna Centrum in between them.

column2: Solna's built-up areas have a suburban character
column3: but there are also several large parks and Friends Arena
column4: Sweden's new national football stadium adjacent to the Solna station of Stockholm commuter rail.

column1: The final matches of both the 1958 FIFA (men's) World Cup and the 1995 FIFA Women's World Cup were played at Råsunda Stadium
column2: the national football stadium from 1937 to 2012 (demolished in 2013).

column1: Solna has attracted a wide range of businesses and authorities
column2: making it a major place of work in Greater Stockholm. Among the most important employers are the medical university Karolinska Institutet and the Karolinska University Hospital. The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) are also located in Solna.

column1: The population in Solna Municipality has the 16th highest median income per capita in Sweden
column2: although the share of highly educated persons
column3: according to Statistics Sweden's definition: persons with post-secondary education that is three years or longer
column4: is 46.0% (national average: 27.0%) and the 5th highest in the country.

column1: On 31 December 2017 the number of people with a foreign background (persons born outside of Sweden or with two parents born outside of Sweden) was 30 601
column2: or 38.39% of the population (79 707 on 31 December 2017). On 31 December 2002 the number of residents with a foreign background was (per the same definition) 14 986
column3: or 26.02% of the population (57 585 on 31 December 2002). On 31 December 2017 there were 79 707 residents in Solna
column4: of which 23 597 people (29.60%) were born in a country other than Sweden. Divided by country in the table below - the Nordic countries as well as the 12 most common countries of birth outside of Sweden for Swedish residents have been included
column5: with other countries of birth bundled together by continent by Statistics Sweden.

column1: As with all 290 municipalities of Sweden
column2: Solna has a municipal assembly (kommunfullmäktige)
column3: holding 61 members elected by proportional representation for a four-year term. An executive committee (kommunstyrelse) is appointed by its members.

column1: Solna is centrally located in the Stockholm area and is well served by the Stockholm public transport system with two commuter train stations and six metro stations as well as a dense bus network run by SL. It was served by trams until 1959. Light rail returned after 54 years of absence when Tvärbanan was extended from Alvik to Solna centrum. A further extension to Solna Station opened in 2014.

Mall of Scandinavia has opened in November 2015 and is located in Solna.The head office of Scandinavian Airlines and SAS Group is located in Solna. The airline head office was formerly located on the property of Stockholm Arlanda Airport in Sigtuna Municipality
column2: but now it is back in Solna.

column1: The Solna Church was constructed in the 12th century. For defensive purposes
